comment.author: 70994841@N07
comment._content: A fantastic record of the time and place....but it makes me sad to see it.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I used to think of this photo every time I walked up West Street on the way to work, and would wonder what the rear of no. 7 looked like these days ... State Library of NSW version - www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/5763155265/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Hmm - something about this West Street doesn't add up.  They knocked down these houses to replace them with smaller terraces which look older than 1900 ??  See also the houses on the other side of the street - much further away than they would be if this was the Paddington West St.

My instincts suggest that there was a different West Street off Oxford Street near Wexford Street,  Surry Hills end.

Or not?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Have a look at the nearby photos in the Plague Album. They are all in the vicinity West Street, Paddington (ie. the West Street side of Oxford, Comber, Boundary, Barcom etc ...) acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=413021&amp... [thumbnail page 3] Comber Street (parallel to West Street), looking towards Oxford Street - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823669&am...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Before the hospital, West Street originally extended all the way to the Liverpool / Womerah Street intersection, and the numbering appears to have started at that end, not Oxford. I think this accounts for the present day confusion - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367501.html This was the other end of West Street. No. 7 could have been not far from this corner store - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/4998211732/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Or not! I think this 1890 map shows the cottage concerned, even the steps and the outhouse! Near Oxford after all. - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367555.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks - this really does seem to match the 1890 map.  Still having doubts ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Just came across this zoomable 1903 map showing plague infection areas - red for 1900, blue for 1902. Click on the third map down at www.baseline.nsw.gov.au/exhibitions/maps/infrastructure.html .
